title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Their first work was to construct a new avenue which would lead directly down to the village, avoiding both the gloomy Cleuch of Pluckamin and the yet more tragic memories of the Marches of Barnbarroch.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Besides, in comparison with the great fear that had driven her across the waste and through the Cleuch of Pluckamin, the news had seemed to the girl as nothing.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Presently she was in the long green aisles of Pluckamin Cleuch, the sunset dying high above her in a flurry of aerial seas, multitudinous and incarnadine, flecked with willow leaves of floating gold.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Cleuch of Pluckamin.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: As Adora looked out of the open window she could see the Cleuch of Pluckamin, a deep blue gorge trenched

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Purslane gathered up her scattered properties,  the black satin bag, the bone knitting-needles, the patchwork, and went out mumbling defiantly to herself, "Ye needna be that particular, mistress as if it hadna been me that pit the first notion o't into the head o' ye! I ken ye are gaun to bid him gang and speer the lass he has been granein' for this while the verra lass that yince on a day (and no that lang syne either) ye miscaa'ed like a tinkler's messan on the road up the Cleuch o' Plucka-

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: The Cleuch of Pluckamin rose before  her, and she heard the words : " You you alone have bewitched him ! He left me to seek the Strange Woman.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: I will thank you to keep away from the Cleuch of Pluckamin !"

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: But no she remembered  the countenance of the woman who had cursed her on the road through the Cleuch of Pluckamin.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: THE pair went down the Cleuch of Pluckamin together.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: "I'll tell you," he said, turning and facing her in the deep darks of Pluckamin Cleuch, into which the last struggling  slants of the moonlight could hardly enter, "I'll tell ye, Adora Gracie, what ye aiblins dinna ken yoursel', aye, and what maybe will no thank me for tellin' ye.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: No' that I deny it's pairtly oor ain faut gangin' at one time by the Cleuch and at anither by Bennanbrack,  an' then aiblins the neist time doon the burnside.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: "An' by the time I sand my mistak' and got back, Roy was up the Cleuch o' Pluckamin an' awa' !

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: was anything to be heard save the sough of the wet wind, soft, clammy and spiritless, dank with the smell of rotting leaves, that came up through the woods of Lowran  and the Cleuch of Pluckamin.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: "I heard a shot let aff an' ran up the Cleuch, but I cam' on the keepers rowtin' through the bushes like sae mony elephants, an' was obligated to keep the upper side so as to hae the muir ahint me in case o' need !"

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Having secured that, he crept quietly to the edge of the Cleuch, peering down into its dark depths, and giving the whistle by which he knew Daid would recognise him if he had not already gone home.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: It was curious that as they went back down the Cleuch, searching for a safe point at which to emerge upon the open country, several of Roy's captors were struck by large branches, sir cones, and stones which rattled down from the tree-tops or detached themselves from the precipitous  ledges of the Cleuch.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: It was curious that as they went back down the Cleuch, searching for a safe point at which to emerge upon the open country, several of Roy's captors were struck by large branches, sir cones, and stones which rattled down from the tree-tops or detached themselves from the precipitous  ledges of the Cleuch.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: crossed the Cleuch from side to side on the tree-tops, without  any more motive than to find out whether he could do it or not.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Sticks were breaking under clumsy treading down in the deeps of the Cleuch.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: He could distinctly hear footsteps beneath him down the Cleuch.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: He saw nothing He heard nothing, but borne on the light breeze whic blew down the Cleuch, like the down-draught of a chirr ney, there came the smell of burning tobacco.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Roy usually varied h route homeward, but on this occasion he had to secui his gun, which (as we know) lay hidden at the uppe end of the Cleuch, just where it opens out upon the bar brown face of the heather, and where the bushes stop sue denly, as if cut by the scythe.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: The Cleuch of Pluckamin was n lady's bowling-green.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: The Cleuch was filled from end to end with great pines that stretched their green spreading crowns into the upper air.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: At the foot of the village Strong Mac struck up the braeface, vaulting over a dry-stone dyke and making straight for the corner of the Cleuch of Pluckamin.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Charlotte standing forlornly in the loop of the road, her school-bag abandoned among the muddy leaves in front of her, and her eyes strained upon the dark woods of the Cleuch of Pluckamin, which in the purple gloaming kept their secret impenetrable.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: By this time they were well down the road which passes the entrance of Pluckamin Cleuch.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: By taking the face of the fell, striking into Pluckamin Cleuch and following the left bank of the burn, he would come to a certain inconspicuous  outcrop of rock, and under that rock, wrapped in an old blanket and touched with grease against the damp, he would find a gun.
